- Particulate matter is linked to cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, including heart attacks, strokes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and lung cancer. PM2.5 (particles <2.5 microns) is especially dangerous as it can penetrate deep into the lungs.

- SO2 and NOx react in the atmosphere to form fine particles and acid aerosols, contributing to the same health problems as directly emitted PM. They also cause acid rain which damages ecosystems.

- Mercury accumulates in the food chain and can cause neurological damage, especially in fetuses and young children.

They then apply these risk coefficients to population exposure data to estimate the number of premature deaths attributable to the pollution.

For example, the Global Burden of Disease study (GBD, 2019) estimated that in 2019, 3.3 million deaths were attributable to PM2.5 air pollution from all sources. Coal combustion is a major contributor to PM2.5 levels in many regions.

The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that ambient air pollution (mainly from power plants, industrial facilities, and vehicles) causes 4.2 million premature deaths annually.

So in summary, the deaths attributed to coal power plants come primarily from the health impacts of the particulate matter and other pollutants they emit. The risk coefficients are derived from large epidemiological studies, and the population exposure is assessed using air quality monitoring and modeling.
